awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing the Lambda Cold Dark Matter Paradigm with Dwarf Satellites of Low-mass Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
All large galaxies, like our own Milky Way, are surrounded by many smaller "satellite" companion galaxies. Scientists have recently discovered tiny satellite galaxies around the Large Magellanic Cloud, a small Milky Way companion galaxy. Current predictions are not able to reproduce the numbers and properties of these satellite galaxies. Small "dwarf" galaxies thus challenge our understanding of the physical processes that shape galaxies. To solve the puzzle, this project explores galaxies beyond the Milky Way and its Local Group of galaxies. The investigators will test predictions by searching for the tiniest satellites around small galaxies beyond our Local Group. These satellites are predicted to be faint and can only be found using the most advanced telescopes on Earth. The properties of the new objects will be compared to satellites in our Local Group and interpreted in the context of theoretical models. 

The three investigators, together with a postdoctoral researcher and students, will use state-of-the-art instrumentation on large optical telescopes to perform systematic, panoramic imaging surveys of 11 sub-Milky Way-mass target galaxies. The research team will interpret this census of faint satellites with the aid of dedicated analytical models. The final goal is to inform our understanding of the galaxy formation physics at the lowest mass scales. These observations can reveal how the stellar content of dwarf galaxies relates to their dark matter halos. The results will be interpreted as a function of galaxy environment, halo mass and morphology, thus providing quantitative constraints for star formation, feedback and re-ionization prescriptions in the framework of galaxy formation models.

The Investigators will use this research to increase the involvement of underrepresented minorities in astronomy by developing a support network for women in science at the University of Tampa. This will provide valuable guidance for their future careers and advise them on gender balance issues. At Ohio State University (OSU), astronomy-themed YouTube coding videos will be developed for high school students. Additionally, a peer-mentoring program led by OSU students will be supported by this program through participation in a dedicated Leadership Retreat.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have executed a search for small satellite galaxies (or remnants thereof) around low-mass host galaxies that are beyond the Local Group. To do this, we have performed a deep, panoramic imaging survey covering large areas around nearby galaxies that have stellar masses less than that of the Milky Way. The resulting census of satellites around low-mass host galaxies can be used to assess cosmological model predictions of how faint galaxies inhabit the smallest dark matter halos, and to understand the effects of environment on the number and properties of satellites. These results provide context for understanding the satellite system of the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds, which have recently been demonstrated to have numerous satellites of their own, but for which interpretation is difficult because they reside within the outer regions of the Milky Way.

 

As part of this program, we have comprehensively mapped the area around four nearby, LMC-mass galaxies to depths faint enough to identify their satellites via their individual stars. Thus far, we have discovered (and subsequently characterized in detail via Hubble Space Telescope imaging) the faintest known satellite of a low-mass host galaxy, and a faint dwarf satellite that shows unexpected evidence of recent star formation. We have additionally discovered extensive streams of stars being ripped from the satellite galaxy DDO 44 by the interaction with its host galaxy, NGC 2403. Comparison of this system to models suggests that such interactions are expected to be rare.

 

To understand the sensitivity of our data to dwarf satellites, we injected thousands of artificial dwarf galaxies into the images, then re-ran the data processing and dwarf search algorithms. The tools we have developed allow us to place detailed limits on the presence and physical properties of satellites around the low-mass hosts we are studying. The first host for which we published a comprehensive satellite search was NGC 2403, which has only two satellites above our detection limit. Nonetheless, these two satellites are consistent with expectations from models, and highlight the need for a detailed census of satellites around multiple low-mass hosts to build a statistical sample. This work anticipates and develops tools for the analysis of data from the Vera C. Rubin Observatory’s upcoming Legacy Survey of Space and Time, which will likely discover many dwarf satellites around nearby galaxies.
